articles.headline: Government Spending, Edging Up, Is a Stimulus
articles.snippet: State and local governments are spending on projects that were stalled — like an effort in Naples, Fla., to prevent pelicans from entangling fishing lines — and even some federal spending is rising.
articles.abstract: State and local governments are spending on projects that were stalled — like an effort in Naples, Fla., to prevent pelicans from entangling fishing lines — and even some federal spending is rising.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Fla. — For a long stretch, government spending cutbacks at all levels were a substantial drag on economic growth. Now, finally, relief is in sight.

articles.headline: By ‘Editing’ Plant Genes, Companies Avoid Regulation
articles.snippet: Critics of bioengineered crops are concerned that a technical loophole could lead to the release of plants that could have unintended effects on the environment.
articles.abstract: Critics of bioengineered crops are concerned that a technical loophole could lead to the release of plants that could have unintended effects on the environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Its first attempt to develop genetically engineered grass ended disastrously for the Scotts Miracle-Gro Company. The grass escaped into the wild from test plots in Oregon in 2003, dooming the chances that the government would approve the product for commercial use.

articles.headline: A Year of Columns, a Memorable Trove of Characters
articles.snippet: A columnist meets many characters in the course of a year’s work. Here are a few featured in Common Sense who stood out.
articles.abstract: A columnist meets many characters in the course of a year’s work. Here are a few featured in Common Sense who stood out.
articles.lead_paragraph: HANGING OVER HIS FUTURE For Zachary Warren, the 30-year-old magna cum laude graduate of Georgetown Law School caught up in the 2012 collapse of the big law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, probably the best thing that can be said about 2014 is that it’s over.

articles.headline: Web Freedom Is Seen as a Growing Global Issue
articles.snippet: The new year promises further attempts at online censorship, as the web increasingly serves as a platform for civil rights efforts.
articles.abstract: The new year promises further attempts at online censorship, as the web increasingly serves as a platform for civil rights efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Government censorship of the Internet is a cat-and-mouse game. And despite more aggressive tactics in recent months, the cats have been largely frustrated while the mice wriggle away.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Time to Assess Your Financial Fitness
articles.snippet: To track your financial progress, here are some personal markers you can turn to this year, and every year.
articles.abstract: To track your financial progress, here are some personal markers you can turn to this year, and every year.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 18,000 for the first time late last month, you could practically hear the champagne corks popping. Traders wore hats celebrating the occasion, and email news alerts were followed by dutiful articles.
